rev.comment: what was exactly the point of this section? It is not even controversy
rev.diff:
Line 21: Line 21:
On August 17th, 2007 TorrentFreak reported that [[Comcast]] had begun [[Bandwidth throttling|throttling]] its upload bandwidth, specifically against BitTorrent users. This made [[Seed (BitTorrent)|seeding]], which is an essential part of the BitTorrent protocol, effectively impossible.<ref>[http://www.lightreading.com/document.asp?doc_id=132115 Light Reading - IP & Convergence - Comcast Takes on TorrentFreak - Telecom News Analysis<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It was later determined that Comcast was using [[Sandvine]] products which implement network traffic shaping and policing, and include support for both blocking new and forcefully terminating established network connections. Comcast has denied these claims whenever they have been asked to comment. A guide, for customer service representatives when asked about Comcast's BitTorrent throttling, was leaked to the [[Consumerist (blog)|Consumerist]] on October 26th, 2007.<ref>[http://consumerist.com/consumer/leaks/comcasts-we-dont-throttle-bittorrent-internal-talking-points-memo-315791.php Leaks: Comcast's âWe Don't Throttle BitTorrentâ Internal Talking Points Memo<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
On August 17th, 2007 TorrentFreak reported that [[Comcast]] had begun [[Bandwidth throttling|throttling]] its upload bandwidth, specifically against BitTorrent users. This made [[Seed (BitTorrent)|seeding]], which is an essential part of the BitTorrent protocol, effectively impossible.<ref>[http://www.lightreading.com/document.asp?doc_id=132115 Light Reading - IP & Convergence - Comcast Takes on TorrentFreak - Telecom News Analysis<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It was later determined that Comcast was using [[Sandvine]] products which implement network traffic shaping and policing, and include support for both blocking new and forcefully terminating established network connections. Comcast has denied these claims whenever they have been asked to comment. A guide, for customer service representatives when asked about Comcast's BitTorrent throttling, was leaked to the [[Consumerist (blog)|Consumerist]] on October 26th, 2007.<ref>[http://consumerist.com/consumer/leaks/comcasts-we-dont-throttle-bittorrent-internal-talking-points-memo-315791.php Leaks: Comcast's âWe Don't Throttle BitTorrentâ Internal Talking Points Memo<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
â   â
== Former controversy ==
  â
In October 2007, TorrentFreak was criticized for attributing the temporary shutdown of the Demonoid.com [[BitTorrent Tracker]] to the [[Canadian Recording Industry Association]], when nobody had knowledge of the true reason for the downtime. It was later revealed that TorrentFreak was, in fact, correct in its assertion that Demonoid was shutdown by the CRIA,<ref>[http://www.nu.nl/internet/1249300/torrentsite-demonoid-opnieuw-offline.html nu.nl | Torrentsite Demonoid opnieuw offline]</ref> and that the accusations<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20071011024326/http://www.thecircuitbox.com/demonoid/ Archive.org copy of accusations]</ref> against TorrentFreak, made by Demonoid staff, were false.
